The specific details about where the woman in Australia was bitten or scratched by the bat that transmitted the virus are not publicly available, so it is not clear where on her body the virus entered.

As for the autopsy findings, I could not find any specific information about the course the virus took through her body. However, it is known that after the virus enters the body, it travels to the nervous system, where it can cause inflammation and damage. This can result in a range of symptoms, including fever, headache, muscle weakness, and paralysis, depending on the severity of the infection.

Studies of the virus have provided insights into its life cycle and the threat it poses to hosts. Like other viruses in the lyssavirus family, bat lyssavirus is able to replicate in nerve cells, which allows it to establish a persistent infection in the host. This may contribute to the long incubation period and the ability of the virus to remain dormant in the host for an extended period of time.

Research on bat lyssavirus has also highlighted the importance of public awareness and appropriate management of the risks associated with contact with bats and other wildlife. This includes the development of guidelines for handling and caring for animals, as well as education and outreach programs to promote public awareness of the risks and prevention measures.
